## Awards and Honors

Stanisław Lem received numerous prestigious awards throughout his career, including the City of Kraków's Prize in Literature (1957), the Prize of the Minister of Culture and Art 2nd Level (1965), the Prize of the Minister of Foreign Affairs for popularization of Polish culture abroad (1973), the Literary Prize of the Minister of Culture and Art (1973), and the State Prize 1st Level in the area of literature (1976). He also won the Grand Prix de Littérature Policière for his novel "Katar" in 1979.

In 1973, Lem was awarded honorary membership in the Science Fiction Writers of America (SFWA), though this was later revoked in 1976 due to his scathing evaluations of other sci-fi writers' work.

Lem received several honorary doctorates, including from Wrocław University of Technology (1981), University of Bielefeld (2003), and the Austrian State Prize for European Literature (1986). He also received Polish state decorations including The Medal of the White Eagle.

## Translation History and Global Reception

Lem's books have been translated into more than 50 languages and have sold more than 45 million copies worldwide. In 1976, Theodore Sturgeon wrote that Lem was the most widely read science fiction writer in the world.

According to recent estimates, his books have been translated into more than 40 languages and have sold almost 40 million copies, and he was repeatedly nominated for the Nobel Prize. By all measures he was one of the most successful writers of the 20th century.

Lem was phenomenally popular in Eastern and Central Europe, though today he has fallen into quasi-obscurity, at least in the English-speaking world.

## International Recognition

Worldwide, he is best known as the author of the 1961 novel "Solaris". For his entire body of work, he was shortlisted for The Man Booker International Prize 2005.

A minor planet, 3836 Lem, discovered by Soviet astronomer Nikolai Stepanovich Chernykh in 1979, is named after him. In 2013, two planetoids were named after Lem's literary characters: 343000 Ijontichy and 343444 Halluzinelle. An exoplanet named Pirx was found orbiting the star Solaris in the constellation Pegasus.

In 2011, an elaborate interactive Google Doodle inspired by "The Cyberiad" was created for the 60th anniversary of his first published book. The Polish Parliament declared 2021 to be the Year of Stanisław Lem.

In 2021, the Lem Prize was established by Wrocław University of Science and Technology to commemorate his 100th birthday, awarded annually to young European researchers whose work has potential for positive impact on civilization.
